questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive facial hair growth and deepening of her voice that started 3 months ago. She eats a protein-rich diet and goes to the gym 6 times per week in preparation for an all-natural bodybuilding competition. Six months ago, menses occurred at regular 28-day intervals with moderate flow. Menses now occur at irregular 35- to 45-day intervals and last 2 to 3 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She takes no medications and states that she does not use performance-enhancing drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows dark terminal hair on the chin and upper lip. The patient is very muscular. Pelvic examination shows a normal-appearing vagina, cervix, and uterus. There is a palpable adnexal mass on the right side. Which of the following combinations of serum hormone levels is most likely to be found in this patient?



Testosterone
Dehydroepiandrosterone
Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate
Androstenedione
Dihydrotestosterone



A
Decreased
decreased
decreased
decreased
decreased


B
Increased
decreased
decreased
decreased
increased


C
Increased
increased
increased
increased
decreased


D
Increased
increased
increased
increased
increased


E
Increased
increased
normal
increased
increased


F
Decreased
increased
increased
decreased
decreased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The constellation of decreased levels of testosterone, dehydroepiandrosterone, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate, androstenedione, and dihydrotestosterone is typically seen in 17-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency. This condition causes primary amenorrhea, delayed puberty, a lack of secondary sexual characteristics, and hypertension, all of which are absent in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

The constellation of increased testosterone and dihydrotestosterone levels with decreased levels of dehydroepiandrosterone, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate, and androstenedione is seen in exogenous androgen administration (i.e., androgenic-anabolic steroids), which is not uncommon among athletes trying to boost their performance. Although androgenic-anabolic steroid misuse can cause virilization, this patient states that she does not use such drugs to prepare for her all-natural bodybuilding competition. The presence of a palpable adnexal mass makes the diagnosis of a testosterone-producing ovarian tumor more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of elevated levels of testosterone, dehydroepiandrosterone, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate, and androstenedione with decreased levels of dihydrotestosterone is seen in 5-alpha-reductase deficiency, a condition that manifests with female external genitalia at birth in genetically male patients. In this case, virilization would have already begun at puberty with the increased synthesis of testosterone. Additionally, menses would not occur in 5-alpha-reductase deficiency and normal vagina, cervix, and uterus would not be expected, since the internal urogenital organs would be male.

D) INCORRECT:

The constellation of elevated levels of testosterone, dehydroepiandrosterone, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEA-S), androstenedione, and dihydrotestosterone is typically seen in excess adrenal androgen secretion (e.g., from adrenal hyperplasia, adrenal tumors), as DHEA-S is only produced by the adrenal glands. While adrenal overproduction of androgens can manifest with a clinical picture similar to this patient's presentation, a palpable adnexal mass suggests an ovarian rather than an adrenal cause.

E) CORRECT:

Testosterone-producing ovarian tumors (e.g., Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors) typically manifest with increased levels of testosterone, dehydroepiandrosterone, androstenedione, and dihydrotestosterone. Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate is only produced by the adrenal glands and is not secreted by ovarian tumors. Thus, DHEA-S is normal in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

The combination of elevated levels of dehydroepiandrosterone and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate with decreased levels of testosterone, androstenedione, and dihydrotestosterone is seen in 3-beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency, which most commonly manifests at birth with adrenal insufficiency due to both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid deficiency. While cases with mild defects in 3-beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase activity may manifest with virilization later in life, this patient's presentation with a palpable adnexal mass makes the diagnosis of a testosterone-producing ovarian tumor more likely.
questions.hint: This patient presents with virilization (hirsutism and deepening of the voice) and a palpable adnexal mass, which suggests the diagnosis of a testosterone-producing ovarian tumor.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of intermittent bleeding from her vagina. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Pelvic ultrasound shows a thickened endometrial stripe and a left adnexal mass. Endometrial biopsy shows a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. Laboratory studies show increased levels of inhibin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovarian yolk sac tumors (endodermal sinus tumors) can present as an adnexal mass, as seen here. However, this type of tumor is not associated with endometrial hyperproliferation or adenocarcinoma and would cause elevated levels of AFP, not inhibin.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a testicular tumor sample (H&E stain; very high magnification)

A central blood vessel (red overlay) is surrounded by tumor cells (blue overlay) with enlarged nuclei and coarse chromatin, resulting in a glomerulus-like appearance (Schiller-Duval body).

Schiller-Duval bodies are a classic finding in yolk sac tumors. The diagnosis was confirmed by immunohistochemical findings (positive for α-fetoprotein and glypican 3).

B) INCORRECT:

Although choriocarcinoma may present with irregular vaginal bleeding, which is seen in this patient, it typically occurs in women who recently had a hydatidiform mole or pregnancy, as it arises from trophoblastic tissue. Moreover, choriocarcinoma is characterized by markedly increased levels of serum beta-HCG, not inhibin. Lastly, ultrasound would show destructive growth into the uterine myometrium.

C) CORRECT:

Granulosa cell tumors are the most common sex-cord stromal ovarian tumors. Granulosa cells express aromatase, which converts testosterone to estradiol. Excessive estrogen production leads to adenomatous endometrial hyperproliferation, which can manifest as post-menopausal vaginal bleeding and increases the risk of developing endometrial adenocarcinoma. Inhibin is a hormone specifically produced by granulosa cells; elevated levels aid in the diagnosis of granulosa cell tumors.

Histology of granulosa cell tumors shows Call-Exner bodies, which resemble follicles with eosinophilic secretions.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an ovary tissue sample (H&E stain; low magnification)

Granulosa cells (blue overlay) are arranged in clusters around multiple central cavities (Call-Exner bodies, yellow overlay). The characteristic grooved, “coffee-bean” appearance can be seen in some nuclei.

This is the typical histological appearance of granulosa cell tumors, although the absence of Call-Exner bodies in such tumors is not uncommon and does not rule out the diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Immature ovarian teratomas are rare, aggressive ovarian tumors that can present as an adnexal mass. However, this type of tumor is not associated with endometrial hyperproliferation or elevation of inhibin levels. Moreover, immature ovarian teratomas classically occur in patients under the age of 20 years.

E) INCORRECT:

Serous cystadenocarcinoma is the most common malignant ovarian neoplasm. It is a very aggressive cancer that often presents as an adnexal mass but does not cause endometrial hyperplasia or adenocarcinoma. Moreover, cells of this tumor are derived from surface epithelial cells and would therefore express CA 125, not inhibin. Lastly, serous cystadenocarcinomas are most commonly bilateral, as opposed to this patient's unilateral adnexal mass.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of specimen from an ovarian cystic mass (H&E stain, medium magnification):

The carcinoma has a complex papillary architecture, with stromal cores lined by atypical, intensely staining (serous) epithelial cells. At higher magnification, these cells show hyperchromatic (dark blue staining), pleomorphic nuclei that often contain mitotic or apoptotic figures.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

F) INCORRECT:

Dysgerminoma is an ovarian tumor derived from oocytes and is the most common malignant ovarian tumor in women 20–40 years of age. It is rapidly growing and commonly presents with pelvic pain but does not cause endometrial hyperplasia or adenocarcinoma. Moreover, dysgerminoma would cause elevated levels of beta-HCG and LDH, not inhibin.
questions.hint: This patient's postmenopausal bleeding is most likely due to excessive estrogen production by the ovaries, which is also the underlying cause of endometrial adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 6-month history of breast tenderness and menstrual irregularities. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. An ultrasound of the pelvis shows a right adnexal mass. A laparoscopic right salpingo-oophorectomy is performed. Histologic examination of the adnexal mass shows small cuboidal cells arranged in clusters surrounding a central cavity with eosinophilic secretions. These cells resemble primordial follicles. Which of the following laboratory values was most likely increased in this patient at the time of presentation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A granulosa cell tumor is the most common type of sex cord-stromal tumor and is associated with elevated estrogen and/or progesterone production. Granulosa cell tumors produce aromatase, which converts testosterone to estradiol. Excess production of estrogen can cause breast tenderness and menstrual abnormalities, as seen in this patient. Unopposed estrogen causes the endometrium to proliferate, resulting in abnormal uterine bleeding and an increased risk of endometrial adenocarcinoma.

Although granulosa cell tumors predominantly affect postmenopausal women, in prepubertal girls, the excess estrogen produced by these tumors can cause precocious puberty.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an ovary tissue sample (H&E stain; low magnification)

Granulosa cells (blue overlay) are arranged in clusters around multiple central cavities (Call-Exner bodies, yellow overlay). The characteristic grooved, “coffee-bean” appearance can be seen in some nuclei.

This is the typical histological appearance of granulosa cell tumors, although the absence of Call-Exner bodies in such tumors is not uncommon and does not rule out the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) can be used as a tumor marker for certain ovarian tumors, such as dysgerminomas, which account for approx. 1% of all ovarian tumors. Dysgerminomas can also present as an adnexal mass. However, histologic examination of dysgerminomas would rather show cells with a fried-egg appearance (clear cytoplasm and a large central nucleus), not Call-Exner bodies. In addition to elevated LDH levels, patients with dysgerminomas can present with increased β-hCG levels.

C) INCORRECT:

α-fetoprotein can be used as a tumor marker for certain ovarian germ cell tumors, such as yolk sac tumors (ovarian endodermal sinus tumor). Ovarian germ cell tumors can also present as an adnexal mass. However, histologic examination of yolk sac tumors shows Schiller-Duval bodies (resembling glomeruli of the kidneys) in approx. 50% of cases, not Call-Exner bodies.

D) INCORRECT:

CA 125 is a tumor marker for epithelial ovarian tumors, e.g., serous cystadenocarcinoma, which is the most common type of malignant ovarian tumors. Serous cystadenocarcinomas are most commonly located bilaterally, as opposed to this patient's unilateral adnexal mass. Moreover, histologic examination of serous cystadenocarcinoma would rather show psammoma bodies, not Call-Exner bodies. Granulosa cell tumors are not derived from the ovarian epithelium and therefore do not produce CA 125.
Image Description:

Histopathology slide of the ovary (H&E stain)

In addition to papillary tumor cells, there are two Psammoma bodies located in the lower left corner of the image (red overlay). Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellar calcifications, which are characteristic for serous tumors of the ovary.

E) INCORRECT:

β-hCG is produced by syncytiotrophoblasts and increased during normal pregnancy. Pathologically elevated β-hCG levels are seen in certain gynecological conditions, such as choriocarcinomas and dysgerminomas. Patients with choriocarcinoma often have a history of hydatidiform mole and ultrasound would show destructive growth into the uterine myometrium. Dysgerminomas can also present as an adnexal mass. However, histologic examination of dysgerminomas would rather show cells with a fried-egg appearance (clear cytoplasm and a large central nucleus), not Call-Exner bodies.

F) INCORRECT:

Physiologic effects of FSH include stimulating the growth of primordial follicles. Call-Exner bodies can resemble primordial follicles but they are not controlled by FSH. Patients with granulosa cell tumors instead have decreased FSH levels as a result of an increased inhibin production by granulosa cells.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an ovary tissue sample (H&E stain; low magnification)

Granulosa cells (blue overlay) are arranged in clusters around multiple central cavities (Call-Exner bodies, yellow overlay). The characteristic grooved, “coffee-bean” appearance can be seen in some nuclei.

This is the typical histological appearance of granulosa cell tumors, although the absence of Call-Exner bodies in such tumors is not uncommon and does not rule out the diagnosis.
questions.hint: Histopathology of this patient's adnexal mass shows Call-Exner bodies (granulosa cells resembling primordial follicles), which are characteristic of granulosa cell tumors.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening shortness of breath for the past two weeks. Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds at both lung bases. The abdomen is distended and there is shifting dullness with a positive fluid wave. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows a large collection of peritoneal fluid and a hypoechoic mass involving the left ovary. Histologic evaluation of the surgical specimen after oophorectomy shows clusters of spindle-shaped cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serous cystadenomas are benign epithelial tumors and the most common type of ovarian neoplasm. Histology from a serous cystadenoma would show psammoma bodies and ciliated cells that resemble the normal epithelium of the fallopian tube, unlike the findings in this patient's biopsy. Patients with serous cystadenoma do not usually present with Meigs syndrome.
Image Description:

Histopathology slide of the ovary (H&E stain)

In addition to papillary tumor cells, there are two Psammoma bodies located in the lower left corner of the image (red overlay). Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellar calcifications, which are characteristic for serous tumors of the ovary.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometrioma can be found on the ovaries of patients with endometriosis which usually manifests with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and/or chronic pelvic pain in conjunction with ovarian cysts (chocolate cysts). Histology of an endometrioma would show glandular cells and stroma resembling the endometrium, unlike this patient's findings. Meigs syndrome would not be expected in patients with endometrioma.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) INCORRECT:

Ovarian thecoma is a type of benign sex cord-stromal tumor that can also rarely manifest with Meigs syndrome. However, this tumor typically causes abnormal uterine bleeding as the estrogen produced by theca cells stimulates hyperplasia of the endometrium. Histology of a thecoma would show lipid-containing cells resembling theca interna cells, unlike the findings in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Dermoid cysts are mature cystic teratomas and the most common type of all germ cell tumors. They are usually benign and appear as hypoechoic and hyperechoic areas on ultrasonography. Histology of a dermoid cyst would likely show multiple cell types derived from one or more of the three germ layers, unlike this patient's findings. Patients with dermoid cysts do not usually present with Meigs syndrome.

Gross examination of a dermoid cyst classically shows a mass composed of multiple types of tissue (e.g., hair, teeth, sebaceous material).
Image Description:

Resection specimen of a mature teratoma of the ovary

This sebaceous and solid ovarian tumor contains skin, fat, hair, and cartilage.

Mature teratomas can derive from all three embryological germ layers.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with Meigs syndrome usually have an ovarian fibroma, a type of benign sex cord-stromal tumor. Biopsy in ovarian fibroma typically shows spindle-shaped cells which correspond to fibroblasts. The exact pathomechanism of Meigs syndrome is unknown but symptoms usually resolve with removal of the ovarian fibroma. Pleural effusion is often right-sided but may also be bilateral.
questions.hint: The triad of ascites, pleural effusion, and an ovarian mass is referred to as Meigs syndrome.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of dragging pelvic pain and a 3 kg (6 lb 9 oz) weight loss over the past 6 months. Menses occur at irregular 30- to 45-day intervals; her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), heart rate is 102/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows hyperreflexia. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Ultrasonography shows a 6-cm hypoechoic adnexal mass. This adnexal mass is most likely derived from which of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovarian epithelial cell tumors (e.g., cystadenoma, cystadenocarcinoma, and endometrioid carcinoma) are the most common type of ovarian malignancy and often present with subacute pelvic pain, as seen in this patient. However, ovarian epithelial cell tumors would not cause features of hyperthyroidism.

B) CORRECT:

Ovarian germ cell tumors include mature and immature teratomas, dysgerminoma, yolk sac tumors, and nongestational choriocarcinomas. Struma ovarii is a rare type of mature teratoma that contains > 50% thyroid tissue. These tumors produce excessive thyroxine and present with symptoms consistent with hyperthyroidism, as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Gestational trophoblastic diseases (GTD) are caused by the proliferation of trophoblasts (e.g., chorionic epithelial cells). These cells produce excess beta-hCG, which can result in signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism given the hormone's structural similarity with thyroid-stimulating hormone. GTD can also present with pelvic pain, as seen in this patient. However, a pregnancy test would be positive in patients with GTD. Additionally, ultrasonography would typically show a “snowstorm” pattern of cystic spaces within the uterus, as opposed to the adnexal mass seen on this patient’s imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Ovarian endometriomas (also known as “chocolate cysts”) are derived from endometrial cells. These masses typically present with pelvic pain and are associated with menorrhagia as opposed to oligomenorrhea. Also, ovarian endometriomas would not cause features of hyperthyroidism.

E) INCORRECT:

Granulosa cell tumors and theca cell tumors are derived from stromal cells and produce excess estrogen. Increased estrogen levels result in precocious puberty in pre-adolescents and menorrhagia in adults. This patient has oligomenorrhea as opposed to menorrhagia. Additionally, this patient’s hyperthyroidism is inconsistent with a stromal cell tumor.
questions.hint: This patient with dragging pelvic pain due to a large adnexal mass also has clinical features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, oligomenorrhea, tachycardia, hyperreflexia).

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of facial hair growth, acne, and irregular menses. Her friends have told her that her voice sounds lower than usual. Physical examination shows pustular acne and dark hair growth along the jawline. Serum studies show elevated testosterone levels and normal inhibin levels. An ultrasound of the pelvis shows a left-sided ovarian mass. Microscopic examination of the resected ovarian mass shows pale, testosterone-positive staining cells with cytoplasmic Reinke crystal inclusions. These abnormal cells are homologous to which of the following physiological cell type in females?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Granulosa cells form the immediate cell layer around maturing ovarian follicles. In response to follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), granulosa cells convert incoming androstenedione into estrogen using aromatase. Granulosa cells do not produce androgens and therefore are not homologous to the cell type responsible for the ovarian mass seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Sertoli cells are tall supporting cells of the seminiferous tubules that regulate spermatogenesis. Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) stimulates Sertoli cells to secrete androgen-binding protein (ABP) into the lumen of seminiferous tubules, increasing the local testosterone supply to developing spermatogonia. However, Sertoli cells do not produce testosterone, and the cell type is limited to the male testes.

C) INCORRECT:

In females, germinal epithelial cells form a layer of simple cuboidal epithelium covering the outer cortex of the ovary. The term 'germinal' can be misleading because these cells do not give rise to oocytes. In fact, these cells are mesodermal in origin and serve a function analogous to that of the mesothelium of the peritoneum. Germinal epithelial cells of the ovary do not produce androgens and therefore are not homologous to the cell type responsible for the ovarian mass seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Leydig cells are homologous to the female theca interna cells, which cover the granulosa cell layer of developing ovarian follicles and also secrete testosterone. Theca cells express luteinizing hormone (LH) receptors and, when stimulated, convert cholesterol into androstenedione with the enzyme desmolase. After rupture of the mature ovarian follicle, theca interna cells differentiate into theca-lutein cells, which continue secreting androgens along with progesterone.

E) INCORRECT:

Clue cells are epithelial cells covered by adherent gram-negative rods that are seen in patients with bacterial vaginosis. These cells are observed in vaginal smears and do not contribute to tumor formation.
questions.hint: In combination with an ovarian mass, hirsutism and virilization due to elevated testosterone levels indicate a testosterone-producing tumor. Reinke crystals are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions that are found in Leydig cells.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman, gravida 0, para 0, comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of abdominal distension, constipation, and weight loss. She has a history of endometriosis. Pelvic examination shows a nontender, irregular, left adnexal mass. Her serum level of CA-125 is elevated. Serum concentrations of human chorionic gonadotropin and alpha-fetoprotein are within the reference ranges. Microscopic examination of the mass is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Large undifferentiated germ cells with clear cytoplasm
Flattened, cuboidal cells along with Schiller-Duval bodies
Small, round cells that form Call-Exner bodies
Atypical epithelial cells along with psammoma bodies
Spindle-shaped stromal cells along with signet ring cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Large undifferentiated germ cells with clear cytoplasms are typically found in dysgerminomas, an ovarian tumor derived from oocytes. The well-defined cell boundaries, abundant clear cytoplasm, and central, round nuclei give the cells a fried-egg appearance. Dysgerminoma can manifest as an adnexal mass as seen in this patient. However, it is associated with elevated levels of beta-HCG and LDH, not CA-125.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an ovary tissue specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Sheets of uniform cells with a fried-egg appearance (large nucleus and clear cytoplasm) are visible throughout (examples indicated by green overlay). These sheets of cells are separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytic infiltration.

These findings are consistent with dysgerminoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Immature neuroectodermal tissue is classically found in immature ovarian teratoma, a rare, aggressive ovarian tumor that can manifest as an adnexal mass. However, this type of tumor is not associated with CA-125 elevation and typically occurs in patients ≤ 20 years of age.

C) INCORRECT:

Flattened, cuboidal cells along with Schiller-Duval bodies are the hallmark of ovarian yolk sac tumors (endodermal sinus tumors), which can manifest as an adnexal mass as seen in this patient. However, they are the most common germ cell tumors in children and are not typically seen in elderly patients. Furthermore, this type of tumor is associated with elevated levels of AFP, not CA-125.

D) INCORRECT:

Small, round cells that form Call-Exner bodies are the hallmark feature of granulosa cell tumors, the most common sex-cord stromal ovarian tumors. Granulosa cells express aromatase, which converts testosterone to estradiol. Excessive estrogen production can manifest as post-menopausal vaginal bleeding in older women or as precocious puberty before menarche. This patient does not present with features of excessive estrogen production. Moreover, granulosa cell tumors are associated with elevated levels of Inhibin B, not CA-125.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an ovary tissue sample (H&E stain; low magnification)

Granulosa cells (blue overlay) are arranged in clusters around multiple central cavities (Call-Exner bodies, yellow overlay). The characteristic grooved, “coffee-bean” appearance can be seen in some nuclei.

This is the typical histological appearance of granulosa cell tumors, although the absence of Call-Exner bodies in such tumors is not uncommon and does not rule out the diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Serous cystadenocarcinoma is the most common malignant ovarian neoplasm. It is a very aggressive cancer that often manifests as an adnexal mass. Serous cystadenocarcinomas are often bilateral (65%), although they may be unilateral as in this case. Histologic examination would reveal atypical epithelial cells with papillary structures and small cytoplasms. Psammoma bodies are a common feature.

Endometriosis is associated with an increased risk of epithelial ovarian carcinomas.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of specimen from an ovarian cystic mass (H&E stain, medium magnification):

The carcinoma has a complex papillary architecture, with stromal cores lined by atypical, intensely staining (serous) epithelial cells. At higher magnification, these cells show hyperchromatic (dark blue staining), pleomorphic nuclei that often contain mitotic or apoptotic figures.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

F) INCORRECT:

Spindle-shaped stromal cells along with signet ring cells are the hallmark of Krukenberg tumors, an ovarian malignancy comprised of signet ring cells that have metastasized from a primary site, most commonly the stomach. Although elevated CA-125 levels, as seen here, are a common feature of Krukenberg tumors, they are typically found bilaterally, classically as nodular growths on the ovarian surface. Moreover, a different type of ovarian cancer is much more common.
questions.hint: An irregular adnexal mass in a postmenopausal woman suggests ovarian cancer. Elevated concentrations of CA-125 are seen in ovarian cancers that are derived from the epithelium. The most common epithelial ovarian cancer is serous cystadenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician because of oligomenorrhea and intermittent vaginal spotting for 5 months. Menses previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals and lasted for 5 days with normal flow. She has also noted increased hair growth on her chin. She is not sexually active. She takes no medications. Physical examination shows temporal hair recession and nodulocystic acne on her cheeks and forehead. There is coarse hair on the chin and the upper lip. Pelvic examination shows clitoral enlargement and a right adnexal mass. Laboratory studies show increased serum testosterone concentration; serum concentrations of androstenedione and dehydroepiandrosterone are within the reference ranges. Ultrasonography of the pelvis shows a 10-cm right ovarian tumor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Granulosa cell tumors are potentially malignant ovarian sex cord-stromal tumors that express aromatase, leading to increased conversion of testosterone to estrogen. The most common presentation is postmenopausal bleeding or precocious puberty caused by hyperestrogenism, as opposed to the virilization and increased serum testosterone seen in this patient. A biopsy characteristically shows Call-Exner bodies.

B) INCORRECT:

Ovarian thecomas are generally benign sex cord-stromal tumors that produce estrogen and mainly occur in postmenopausal women. The most common presentation is abnormal uterine bleeding due to estrogen-induced endometrial stimulation, as opposed to the virilization and increased serum testosterone seen in this patient. A biopsy characteristically shows stromal hyperplasia.

C) INCORRECT:

Dermoid cysts are typically benign germ cell tumors that contain elements from all three germ cell layers and are most commonly seen in young women. Although most patients are asymptomatic, some may present with pelvic pain or even ovarian torsion. Dermoid cysts are hormonally inactive, and thus not associated with virilization or increased testosterone. A biopsy characteristically shows endodermal, mesodermal, and ectodermal tissue.

D) INCORRECT:

Ovarian dysgerminomas are malignant germ cell tumors, mainly seen in adolescents and young women. They are characterized by rapid growth, which is why abdominal distension and pelvic pain are the most common presenting symptoms. Although menstrual abnormalities may occur in the case of a hormonally active tumor, ovarian dysgerminomas are not associated with virilization. A biopsy characteristically shows undifferentiated germ cells with a clear cytoplasm known as “fried egg” cells.

E) INCORRECT:

Serous cystadenomas are benign epithelial tumors that are often found incidentally. Most patients are asymptomatic, but some may present with pelvic pain or even ovarian torsion. Serous cystadenomas are hormonally inactive and thus not associated with virilization or increased testosterone. A biopsy characteristically shows psammoma bodies and fallopian tube epithelium with papillary folds.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms of virilization (e.g., oligomenorrhea, hirsutism, male pattern baldness, acne, and clitoral enlargement) in combination with increased serum testosterone and an ovarian mass on ultrasound raise suspicion for a Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor. Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors are rare ovarian sex cord-stromal tumors characterized by androgen-producing testicular structures. They are most commonly found in women aged 30–40 and may be malignant or benign. Treatment consists of surgical excision and in some cases adjuvant chemotherapy.
questions.hint: An excisional biopsy of the tumor will most likely show compressed tubules surrounded by fibrous stroma and intracytoplasmic crystals of Reinke.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well and has no personal or family history of serious illness. Her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive. Menarche occurred at 15 years of age. Menses occur at regular 29-day intervals and last 5 days with normal flow. She is sexually active with one male partner and does not use condoms. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 108/72 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a nontender left adnexal mass. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Ultrasonography shows a 5-cm echogenic, complex mass in the left adnexa. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mucinous cystadenomas are the second most common benign ovarian tumor, are often asymptomatic, and most are diagnosed incidentally on pelvic ultrasonography. However, ultrasonography in mucinous cystadenomas typically shows a large multilocular cystic mass with thin septations without solid components. Moreover, the peak incidence of mucinous cystadenomas is 30–50 years of age, and this patient is 21 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Ovarian thecomas may be asymptomatic and are often found incidentally on physical examination or as an ovarian mass on pelvic ultrasonography. However, ovarian thecomas are very rare and usually occur in postmenopausal women. Furthermore, pelvic ultrasonography most commonly shows a well-demarcated, hypoechoic solid mass with smooth and clear margins, rather than a complex mass. Moreover, ovarian thecomas commonly manifest with symptoms of estrogen excess (e.g., abnormal uterine bleeding, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial neoplasia).

C) INCORRECT:

Serous cystadenocarcinomas are the most common malignant ovarian tumors and can manifest as a complex mass on pelvic ultrasound. However, patients are most often older women who present with symptoms such as abdominal pain or abnormal vaginal bleeding. Moreover, this patient has no risk factors for malignant epithelial carcinomas of the ovary (e.g., family history, genetic predisposition, endometriosis, early menarche, late menopause).

D) CORRECT:

Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) are benign germ cell tumors that can manifest as a nontender palpable adnexal mass, which is seen here. Most patients are asymptomatic, and dermoid cysts are frequently diagnosed incidentally on pelvic ultrasonography. Larger teratomas can manifest with increased abdominal girth, pressure symptoms (e.g., urinary frequency, bloating), and lower abdominal pain. Ultrasonography typically shows a heterogeneous mass with a hyperechoic nodule, echogenic shadowing, calcifications, lack of internal vascularity, and/or fluid-fluid levels. In patients of reproductive age, the treatment of choice is ovarian cystectomy, which confirms the diagnosis and prevents complications (e.g., rupture, ovarian torsion, malignant transformation).
Image Description:

Ultrasound of the right ovary

A partially cystic (white overlay), partially solid tumor (green overlay) of the ovary with an approximate diameter of 35 mm can be seen.

This finding is consistent with a dermoid cyst (mature teratoma).

E) INCORRECT:

Corpus luteum cysts may be asymptomatic and are often diagnosed incidentally on physical examination and pelvic ultrasonography. However, a corpus luteum cyst manifests as a simple ovarian cyst with diffusely thick walls that have increased vascularity (“ring of fire” sign) and sometimes intracystic hemorrhage, none of which is seen here. Moreover, combined oral contraceptive pills, which this patient is currently taking, inhibit the development of corpus luteum cysts by suppressing ovulation, making this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient has the most common ovarian tumor in patients < 30 years of age.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 23-year-old woman reports diffuse lower abdominal pain that has persisted for the past month and worsened during the past 2 weeks. She has had no nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or dysuria. She reports no abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge.
Her vital signs are within normal limits, and she generally appears well. Her heart and lung examinations are normal. Her abdomen is mildly distended but soft with normoactive bowel sounds. On bimanual examination, there is mild tenderness in the left adnexa, and a mass is palpated in the left lower quadrant.
Ultrasound reveals a 12-cm, mostly solid adnexal mass. Screening laboratory tests reveal the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
11,000
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
12.0
12.0–16.0


Hematocrit (%)
36.0
36.0–46.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
450,000
150,000–350,000


Beta human chorionic gonadotropin (mIU/mL)
0.5
<5.0


Alpha-fetoprotein (ng/mL)
1000
<15


Lactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)
120
100–190


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovarian torsion can manifest as an adnexal mass, but the onset of pain is typically more acute than in this patient, and there is no elevation of tumor markers.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings are concerning for a germ-cell tumor, specifically a yolk sac tumor.

Germ-cell tumors are the most common solid tumors in adolescents and young adults — and can be either intracranial or extracranial. Extracranial germ-cell tumors include yolk sac tumors, embryonal carcinomas, choriocarcinomas, and mixed tumors. These tumors often manifest with abdominal pain and distention associated with a palpable pelvic-abdominal mass. Less common manifestations include fever, vaginal bleeding, and acute abdominal pain caused by torsion or rupture.

Secreted tumor markers are used to classify extracranial germ-cell tumors and may also be used to monitor treatment response and subclinical recurrence. The large majority of yolk sac tumors secrete alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) but not beta human chorionic gonadotropin (b-hCG). This patient has a markedly elevated AFP level and a normal b-hCG level.

Key learning point: The tumor marker most likely to be elevated in a yolk sac tumor is alpha-fetoprotein.

C) INCORRECT:

Teratomas are the most common type of germ-cell tumor, and most (but not all) are benign. Mature teratomas, cystic or solid, tend to be benign and have low AFP levels. Immature teratomas are malignant, and there are occasional case reports of immature teratomas with elevated AFP levels. However, immature teratomas comprise less than 1% of all germ-cell tumors. The level of AFP elevation in this patient is therefore more likely to represent a yolk sac tumor.

D) INCORRECT:

Neuroblastomas are very rare in adults and are seen almost exclusively in children. More than half are abdominal tumors but not arising from the ovaries.

E) INCORRECT:

Ovarian cysts are typically associated with pain that is more cyclical or, in the case of rupture, more acute than this patient is experiencing. In addition, the AFP, LDH, and b-hCG levels would all be normal with an ovarian cyst.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 16-year-old girl reports diffuse lower abdominal pain that has persisted for the past month and worsened during the past 2 weeks. She has had no nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or dysuria. She denies sexual activity and reports no abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge.
Her vital signs are within normal limits for her age, and she generally appears well. Her heart and lung examinations are normal. Her abdomen is mildly distended but soft with normoactive bowel sounds. On bimanual examination, there is mild tenderness in the left adnexa, and a mass is palpated in the left lower quadrant.
Ultrasound reveals a 12-cm, mostly solid adnexal mass. Screening laboratory tests reveal the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)

Alpha-fetoprotein (ng/mL)
1000
<15


Lactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)
120
100–190


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neuroblastomas are very rare in teenagers. More than half are abdominal tumors but not arising from the ovaries.

B) INCORRECT:

Ovarian cysts are typically associated with pain that is more cyclical or, in the case of rupture, more acute than this patient is experiencing. In addition, the AFP, LDH, and b-hCG levels would all be normal with an ovarian cyst.

C) INCORRECT:

Teratomas are the most common type of germ-cell tumor, and most (but not all) are benign. Mature teratomas, cystic or solid, tend to be benign and have low AFP levels. Immature teratomas are malignant, and there are occasional case reports of immature teratomas with elevated AFP levels. However, immature teratomas comprise less than 1% of all germ-cell tumors. The level of AFP elevation in this patient is therefore more likely to represent a yolk sac tumor.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings are concerning for a germ-cell tumor, specifically a yolk sac tumor.

Germ-cell tumors are the most common solid tumors in adolescents and young adults — and can be either intracranial or extracranial. Extracranial germ-cell tumors include yolk sac tumors, embryonal carcinomas, choriocarcinomas, and mixed tumors. These tumors often manifest with abdominal pain and distention associated with a palpable pelvic-abdominal mass. Less common manifestations include fever, vaginal bleeding, and acute abdominal pain caused by torsion or rupture.

Secreted tumor markers are used to classify extracranial germ-cell tumors and may also be used to monitor treatment response and subclinical recurrence. The large majority of yolk sac tumors secrete alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) but not beta human chorionic gonadotropin (b-hCG). This patient has a markedly elevated AFP level and a normal b-hCG level.

Key learning point: The tumor marker most likely to be elevated in a yolk sac tumor is alpha-fetoprotein.

E) INCORRECT:

Ovarian torsion can manifest as an adnexal mass, but the onset of pain is typically more acute than in this patient, and there is no elevation of tumor markers.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the office for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well and has no personal or family history of serious illness. Her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive. Menses occur at regular 29-day intervals and last 5 days with normal flow. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a nontender left adnexal mass. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Ultrasonography shows a 5-cm echogenic, complex mass in the left adnexa. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mucinous cystadenomas are the second most common benign ovarian tumor, are often asymptomatic, and most are diagnosed incidentally on pelvic ultrasonography. However, ultrasonography in mucinous cystadenomas typically shows a large multilocular cystic mass with thin septations without solid components. Moreover, the peak incidence of mucinous cystadenomas is 30–50 years of age, and this patient is 21 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Ovarian thecomas may be asymptomatic and are often found incidentally on physical examination or as an ovarian mass on pelvic ultrasonography. However, ovarian thecomas are very rare and usually occur in postmenopausal women. Furthermore, pelvic ultrasonography most commonly shows a well-demarcated, hypoechoic solid mass with smooth and clear margins, rather than a complex mass. Moreover, ovarian thecomas commonly manifest with symptoms of estrogen excess (e.g., abnormal uterine bleeding, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial neoplasia).

C) INCORRECT:

Serous cystadenocarcinomas are the most common malignant ovarian tumors and can manifest as a complex mass on pelvic ultrasound. However, patients are most often older women who present with symptoms such as abdominal pain or abnormal vaginal bleeding. Moreover, this patient has no risk factors for malignant epithelial carcinomas of the ovary (e.g., family history, genetic predisposition, endometriosis, early menarche, late menopause).

D) CORRECT:

Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) are benign germ cell tumors that can manifest as a nontender palpable adnexal mass, which is seen here. Most patients are asymptomatic, and dermoid cysts are frequently diagnosed incidentally on pelvic ultrasonography. Larger teratomas can manifest with increased abdominal girth, pressure symptoms (e.g., urinary frequency, bloating), and lower abdominal pain. Ultrasonography typically shows a heterogeneous mass with a hyperechoic nodule, echogenic shadowing, calcifications, lack of internal vascularity, and/or fluid-fluid levels. In patients of reproductive age, the treatment of choice is ovarian cystectomy, which confirms the diagnosis and prevents complications (e.g., rupture, ovarian torsion, malignant transformation).
Image Description:

Ultrasound of the right ovary

A partially cystic (white overlay), partially solid tumor (green overlay) of the ovary with an approximate diameter of 35 mm can be seen.

This finding is consistent with a dermoid cyst (mature teratoma).

E) INCORRECT:

Corpus luteum cysts may be asymptomatic and are often diagnosed incidentally on physical examination and pelvic ultrasonography. However, a corpus luteum cyst manifests as a simple ovarian cyst with diffusely thick walls that have increased vascularity (“ring of fire” sign) and sometimes intracystic hemorrhage, none of which is seen here. Moreover, combined oral contraceptive pills, which this patient is currently taking, inhibit the development of corpus luteum cysts by suppressing ovulation, making this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient has the most common ovarian tumor in patients < 30 years of age.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with a two-month history of intermittent lower abdominal pain. She has no significant past medical history. A pelvic ultrasound reveals a 5-cm cystic mass in the left ovary with both echogenic and hypoechoic components. During an exploratory laparotomy, the mass contains hair and thick, fatty material. Pathology shows abundant sebaceous debris and adipose tissue (see report).
Pelvic ultrasound: 5-cm cystic mass in the left ovary with both echogenic and hypoechoic components
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mucinous cystadenomas are epithelial tumors forming large, multilocular cysts filled with mucinous material. They are lined by mucin-producing columnar epithelium and lack components from other germ cell layers, such as hair or sebaceous material. The presence of hair and fatty material in the mass excludes mucinous cystadenoma.

B) CORRECT:

Mature cystic teratoma, also known as an ovarian dermoid cyst, contains well-differentiated tissues from multiple germ cell layers, predominantly ectodermal elements like hair, skin, and sebaceous glands. The presence of hair and thick, fatty material in the cyst is characteristic. On ultrasound, mixed echogenic and hypoechoic components reflect its heterogeneous contents, including fat and sometimes calcifications. This condition is common in women of reproductive age, and the intraoperative findings of sebaceous debris and adipose tissue confirm the diagnosis.

Key learning point: A cystic ovarian mass leaking thick fatty material is characteristic of a mature cystic teratoma, also known as a dermoid cyst.

C) INCORRECT:

Endometriomas, or 'chocolate cysts,' typically appear as homogenous masses with a ground-glass appearance on ultrasound due to old blood content. They lack complex features like hair or fatty material. Intraoperatively, they contain brown fluid, not hair or sebaceous debris.

D) INCORRECT:

Serous cystadenomas are benign ovarian neoplasms presenting as unilocular cysts with clear fluid. They are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium and do not contain multi-germ layer elements like hair or sebaceous material. The presence of these elements excludes serous cystadenoma.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to your clinic with worsening shortness of breath over the past two weeks. On examination, breath sounds are decreased at both lung bases. Her abdomen is distended, and there is shifting dullness with a positive fluid wave. Abdominal ultrasound reveals a large amount of peritoneal fluid and a hypoechoic mass involving the left ovary. Histologic evaluation of the oophorectomy specimen shows clusters of spindle-shaped cells. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovarian thecoma is a type of benign sex cord-stromal tumor that can also rarely manifest with Meigs syndrome. However, this tumor typically causes abnormal uterine bleeding as the estrogen produced by theca cells stimulates hyperplasia of the endometrium. Histology of a thecoma would show lipid-containing cells resembling theca interna cells, unlike the findings in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Serous cystadenomas are benign epithelial tumors and the most common type of ovarian neoplasm. Histology from a serous cystadenoma would show psammoma bodies and ciliated cells that resemble the normal epithelium of the fallopian tube, unlike the findings in this patient's biopsy. Patients with serous cystadenoma do not usually present with Meigs syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with Meigs syndrome usually have an ovarian fibroma, a type of benign sex cord-stromal tumor. Biopsy in ovarian fibroma typically shows spindle-shaped cells which correspond to fibroblasts. The exact pathomechanism of Meigs syndrome is unknown but symptoms usually resolve with removal of the ovarian fibroma. Pleural effusion is often right-sided but may also be bilateral.

Key learning point: Ovarian fibroma is a benign sex cord-stromal tumor associated with Meigs syndrome, which presents with ascites, pleural effusion, and a solid ovarian mass composed of spindle-shaped fibroblasts.

D) INCORRECT:

Endometrioma can be found on the ovaries of patients with endometriosis which usually manifests with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and/or chronic pelvic pain in conjunction with ovarian cysts (chocolate cysts). Histology of an endometrioma would show glandular cells and stroma resembling the endometrium, unlike this patient's findings. Meigs syndrome would not be expected in patients with endometrioma.

E) INCORRECT:

Dermoid cysts are mature cystic teratomas and the most common type of all germ cell tumors. They are usually benign and appear as hypoechoic and hyperechoic areas on ultrasonography. Histology of a dermoid cyst would likely show multiple cell types derived from one or more of the three germ layers, unlike this patient's findings. Patients with dermoid cysts do not usually present with Meigs syndrome.

Gross examination of a dermoid cyst classically shows a mass composed of multiple types of tissue (e.g., hair, teeth, sebaceous material).
questions.hint: The triad of ascites, pleural effusion, and an ovarian mass is referred to as Meigs syndrome.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to your clinic for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well and has no personal or family history of serious illness. Her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive. Her menses occur at regular 29-day intervals and last 5 days with normal flow. Vital signs are normal. On pelvic examination, you find a nontender left adnexal mass. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Ultrasonography reveals a 5-cm echogenic, complex mass in the left adnexa. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mucinous cystadenomas are the second most common benign ovarian tumor, are often asymptomatic, and most are diagnosed incidentally on pelvic ultrasonography. However, ultrasonography in mucinous cystadenomas typically shows a large multilocular cystic mass with thin septations without solid components. Moreover, the peak incidence of mucinous cystadenomas is 30–50 years of age, and this patient is 21 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Ovarian thecomas may be asymptomatic and are often found incidentally on physical examination or as an ovarian mass on pelvic ultrasonography. However, ovarian thecomas are very rare and usually occur in postmenopausal women. Furthermore, pelvic ultrasonography most commonly shows a well-demarcated, hypoechoic solid mass with smooth and clear margins, rather than a complex mass. Moreover, ovarian thecomas commonly manifest with symptoms of estrogen excess (e.g., abnormal uterine bleeding, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial neoplasia).

C) INCORRECT:

Serous cystadenocarcinomas are the most common malignant ovarian tumors and can manifest as a complex mass on pelvic ultrasound. However, patients are most often older women who present with symptoms such as abdominal pain or abnormal vaginal bleeding. Moreover, this patient has no risk factors for malignant epithelial carcinomas of the ovary (e.g., family history, genetic predisposition, endometriosis, early menarche, late menopause).

D) INCORRECT:

Corpus luteum cysts may be asymptomatic and are often diagnosed incidentally on physical examination and pelvic ultrasonography. However, a corpus luteum cyst manifests as a simple ovarian cyst with diffusely thick walls that have increased vascularity (“ring of fire” sign) and sometimes intracystic hemorrhage, none of which is seen here. Moreover, combined oral contraceptive pills, which this patient is currently taking, inhibit the development of corpus luteum cysts by suppressing ovulation, making this diagnosis unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) are benign germ cell tumors that can manifest as a nontender palpable adnexal mass. Most patients are asymptomatic, and dermoid cysts are frequently diagnosed incidentally on pelvic ultrasonography. Larger teratomas can manifest with increased abdominal girth, pressure symptoms (e.g., urinary frequency, bloating), and lower abdominal pain. Ultrasonography typically shows a heterogeneous mass with a hyperechoic nodule, echogenic shadowing, calcifications, lack of internal vascularity, and/or fluid-fluid levels. In patients of reproductive age, the treatment of choice is ovarian cystectomy, which confirms the diagnosis and prevents complications (e.g., rupture, ovarian torsion, malignant transformation).

Key learning point: A dermoid cyst (mature cystic teratoma) is a benign ovarian tumor in reproductive-age women, often presenting as a nontender, complex, echogenic adnexal mass with calcifications on ultrasound.
Image Description:

Ultrasound of the right ovary

A partially cystic (white overlay), partially solid tumor (green overlay) of the ovary with an approximate diameter of 35 mm can be seen.

This finding is consistent with a dermoid cyst (mature teratoma).
questions.hint: This patient has the most common ovarian tumor in patients < 30 years of age.
